The historical wild poliovirus cases in Africa since 2011 have been 257, 128, 274, 44, 0 (ending in 2015). The trend has been noticeably downwards. Afganistan and Pakistan, however, continue to have infected each year. Their infected rate has been (since 2011) 278, 95, 107, 334, 74 (ending 2015). Thru June 28th of 2016, there have been 18 confirmed wild cases in Afganistan and Pakistan, compared to 29 the prior year during the same time period. Although the level of infected in the neighboring region is low and the region Africa has been without infection for 22 months (Aug '14 - Jun '16), there is still risk of infection, in my opinion.  I do not know of a way to quantify the risk, so I'll think in terms of 10% of risk. I think it is less than a 50% chance they get infected, probably less than 20%, but more than 10%. So i'll split the difference.

COMMENT:   India had advantages in its fight against polio that Africa doesn't have:
1)  one, unified, functioning government
2)  peace & stability
3)  better infrastructure and access
4)  wide, general acceptance of western medicine. It is the absence of these things in Africa that make me hesitant to raise my forecast much.

Polio eradication efforts appear to have been tremendously successful in Africa (the last documented case of polio was in 2014)--much more so than in the hinterlands of Afghanistan and Pakistan, where suspicion of health workers hampers international efforts.  Yet, despite the very mixed political stability of African regimes, this issue does not seem to be as much of a barrier.  If the continent were more stable, I'd give its chances of remaining free of polio a higher rating.  However, polio has a variable incubation period (with a case report as long as 12 years!) and does not cause symptoms in the majority of people who are infected.   The human infected pool could still be significant in Africa, and any of those people could, in theory, begin to display symptoms if their immune systems were to be compromised, as with HIV, for example. http://www.who.int/topics/poliomyelitis/polio-free/en/

http://www.humanosphere.org/global-health/2016/04/the-end-of-polio-is-nearish/ ". . . It is possible we could see the final case ever [worldwide] within the next year, the World Health Organization’s director of polio eradication told the Guardian today. With so few cases in recent years and improved vaccination campaigns, the end may really be near.  But we’ve heard this before.  . . .  "The [worldwide] polio eradication effort started in 1988 with the aim of reaching zero cases of the wild form of the virus by 2000. Experts were skeptical given the fact that prior initiatives failed to achieve their eradication goals, such as the push against malaria starting in 1955 and against measles in 1977. . . .  "Major gains were made,. . . but the effort failed to reach its 2000 goal. The campaign gained wider attention when the Gates Foundation joined the eradication push in 2005. Billions of dollars were injected into the effort in recent years – far exceeding the financial contributions of groups like Rotary International. As time went on and the difficult task of finishing the last mile dragged on, the projected end dates kept pushing out. "The foundation put forward $1.8 billion in 2013 with the hopes of eradicating polio by 2018. Last year, Gates said the virus may be eradicated by 2019 and earlier this year he raised the possibility that the last case could be seen this year.  “We need some good execution and a little bit of luck,” Gates said at the World Economic Forum in January. "Right now the effort is seeing some good luck. . . .  ". . . But this does not mean all is clear. Even when cases are eliminated, it is possible for flare-ups. That is especially the case in countries where unrest and violence can cut off basic health services. Iraq, Nigeria and Syria all had cases return in 2013 after achieving eradication. Instability in Iraq allowed for cases to emerge and then cross into Syria as it dealt with its ongoing civil war. Similarly, the return of polio to Mali and Ukraine came as the countries dealt with fighting. “When ‘gaps’ in immunization occur, the virus can continue to circulate from person to person. In addition, since the virus can be spread through feces, if there’s inadequate sanitation, sewage mixed with the water supply might be another possible route for transmission,” . . .  ". . . . the end may be here. But as Yogi Berra once said, “It ain’t over till it’s over.”
~~~~~~~

I gave Africa, a notoriously underdeveloped and disease-riddled continent a high chance of not having a single case of polio for a few reasons. In 1988, the Global Polio Eradication initiative was created in response to the astonishingly high rate of polio in the world. This gained a lot of attention, and many people have been committed to the cause. Although Polio was a major problem in Africa in the 2000’s, the problem has been slowly brought under control. August 11 of 2015 marked the first time in history when there was not a single recorded case in the entire continent of Africa. This means that Africa has been polio-free for over a year and a half. Although other diseases caused by viruses may bring the attention away from polio, this is unlikely, as many organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO) have stressed the importance of completely eradicating the Wild Poliovirus.

Moving up a bit, mainly reflecting the elimination of Type 2 and the upcoming switch to bi-valent vaccines. Afghanistan and Pakistan continue as the two remaining reservoirs.

In 2014, WPV (wild polio virus) reappeared in seven countries previously given the all clear[1], so reinfection is certainly possible. The only two countries with on-going infections of WPV are Pakistan and Afghanistan, with a total of 6 reported cases between them. Vaccination efforts are on-going, but it's difficult in areas facing unrest. There is also a case of circulating vaccine-derived polio virus (cVDPV) to contend with, though the vaccinations causing this are being phased out. On the other hand, with only 6 cases of WPV and 1 of cVDPV at this time, the effective; although not formal; eradication of polio is a genuine prospect by the end of the year. Further, there's 10 months until the end of the year, so a high estimate should be made. It's hard to arrive at a sensible base rate for this, though my best guess of a re-infection rate put's it at 1.7% per country per year, but it's trending downwards. With 55 countries in Africa, and only 10 months to go, this would indicate to me that an estimate of 70.2% is most supported by the raw data. However, there should be a significant swing from the facts above: the low number of cases, the phasing out of the cVDPC-causing vaccine, the prospect of an effective elimination of polio. I think I'll settle somewhere in the mid-to-high 90s. [1]: Polio: For Travellers, CDC http://www.cdc.gov/polio/us/travelers.html

Reaffirming, but followers beware.  I'm away this month to places with sketchy internet so I haven't been posting as often.  I spoke with an African guy yesterday who tried to sell me a pile of cast copper bronze items from the Dogon culture.  This may seem to be an irrelevant experience, but bear with me.  The items were representational human figures of various types.  He told me they came from Niger and Mali.  You can check examples of Dogon artifacts displayed in major museums.  Another source, the Saturday edition of the WSJ, tells the sad tale of what you could call the new evangelical form of Islam that is creating mahem in these countries.  The small story effect is that fearful people are packing up bundles of representational sculpture and selling them for scrap because they don't want to get caught with anti-Islamic items that depict the human form.  The big story effect is chaos across the mid-section of the continent.  If you sweep these disparate pieces together, you come back around to the main concern for this question.   War and civil disorder can mess up the great work being done by public health authorities.  There are so many places in Africa where social disintegration reigns, and in many of these places media attention is sparse.  There is a lot of population movement.  I'm still betting on a positive result for this question, but it's no sure thing.

Updating for passage of time and no news of a spread of the poliovirus.
I want to also factor in the concern of previously undetected and unreported wild polio cases in Africa for 2015.

There were 0 cases of native wild polio in Africa in 2015, 6 in 2014 (in Nigeria)  and 50 (in Nigeria) in 2013.  
In 2015 there were 66 wild polio cases in the world: all in  Afghanistan and Pakistan. with no importations to other countries.    There were 19 cases imported to other countries in 2014.  17 of these were in Africa.  This is down from 224 cases imported to Africa in 2013.  (http://www.polioeradication.org/Mediaroom/NewsletterPolioNews.aspx) If polio arises within Africa, it will likely be in Nigeria.  If it is imported, it will likely come from Afghanistan or Pakistan. Worldwide and in each individual country there is a continued downward trend in polio cases since 2010.  
Efforts at vaccination continue and are aggressive.  Political destabilization could effect these programs, and provides the largest uncertainty factor for this prediction.

The overall likelihood seems overstated.   What is the relationship of the level of immunization in the diverse populations of Africa relative to the level required to end the transmission of the virus?  If local conditions are varied and complex then could there be a possibility of silent circulation without symptoms over the time period of the question.  For Africa (Nigeria, Somalia) it seems possible that the extent of immunization is hard to ascertain in the local populations and that there could be some silent circulation.  Kalkowska, Tebbens, Pallansch, Cochi, Wassilak, and Thompson (BMC Infectious Diseases, 2015, 15:66) raise this issue and suggest that a longer time period may be necessary to achieve 95% confidence about eradication.

The only cases of wild poliovirus in 2015 were in Pakistan and Afghanistan (http://www.polioeradication.org/Dataandmonitoring/Poliothisweek/Poliocasesworldwide.aspx). This means it is no longer endemic to any part of Africa. I am putting likelihood of transmission by land travel to Africa at 0, as it would require passage through no fewer than 4 countries, a process that would undoubtedly call an emergency action into play. I think the most useful example of importation by sea/air is a 2007 case of polio in Australia that was imported by a student who visited Pakistan (http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/15/1/08-0791_article). Since then, there have been no other importations from non-neighboring countries. While I'm sure I'm violating tons of statistical rules and committing significant bias, a simple probability saying 8/9 past years have had no imports of wild poliovirus (outside of neighboring countries) is good enough for me to predict 8/9 or 89% chance that Africa will remain disease free. Seeing as we're 1/12 of the way through the year, I'll say it's 1-((1/9)*11/12)=90%.

I started with 80 % in January and will now each month increase my forecast by about 2 percent.

I'd been keeping this number lower given the warnings about the risk of resurgence by health officials -- but it now occurs to me that there's a chance that health officials have an incentive to overstate the risk (in order to keep attention focused on the problem, in order to keep funding, etc.) This doesn't mean that they *are* necessarily overstating the risk -- in fact, I don't think it's likely that they are -- but I'm going to put a bit less weight on their warnings as an adjustment.

Following Khalid, mostly -- they seem to have spent a lot of time thinking about this, and they have the same concerns I do. This is an interesting question, because as time goes on, two opposing factors determine the risk: 1) The areas where wild polio is present become smaller and smaller as the virus dies out with no human hosts to infect
2) Governments drop their guards as "eradication" becomes "resilience" and funding drops off. I wound up with a slightly more optimistic prediction than Khalid after checking on the history of smallpox eradication. I'd expected that, in an era when the world was poorer, technology was weaker, and our knowledge was lesser, factor (2) above would have led to a series of cases popping up just when we thought we'd won, over and over again. But that doesn't seem to have happened -- once we'd reached a state of control over smallpox similar to the control we have today over polio, smallpox disappeared very quickly. Today, we know more about epidemiology, risk communication, and every other discipline relevant to disease eradication than we did in 1975. I don't know how well polio survives in the wild compared to smallpox, but every other factor is on our side (save perhaps for people traveling more often on average, and regional populations being denser, so that any isolated patch of ground has a greater chance of being crossed -- though I don't know whether this is true in rural Nigeria given the pace of migration to cities). Anyway, to sum things up: Had this question been asked about smallpox at the same stage of the game in 1975, the optimists would've been correct. I think there's a good chance they'll also be correct about polio, given our superior ability to handle the problem in the modern era. (Honestly, it's also something of a gut feeling, and I'm trying not to stray too far from 50/50.) * * * * * Note: In the year smallpox was eradicated, something like 3000 people were infected in March. By October, it was down to three new infections, and then zero. This was in Somalia, a country with very few roads and a large population of nomads who were hard to track down. Nigeria seems like an easier place to keep infectious disease under control. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali_Maow_Maalin#Smallpox_eradication_in_Africa On the other hand, polio is harder to keep track of than smallpox given the high rate of asymptomatic infection, so there are more factors to balance out. I'm very uncertain about this prediction. http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/85/07-100107/en/

Poliovirus is spread mainly through fecal-oral transmission and to a lesser extent, via the oral-oral route. Basic sanitation and access to clean water is necessary to help curb the spread of infections and the lack of either of these can support low level transmission. Moreover, viral shedding can still occur in individuals who have been vaccinated ( http://www.livescience.com/52004-polio-virus-gut-shedding.html ), even for almost 30 years as in the linked UK case. At the same time, humans are the only natural known hosts of the virus, which potentially eliminates other species as wild reservoirs ( http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0042682205005830 ).

Polio is such a tough disease to control.  Even highly advanced countries like Israeli have found it (by surprise) in their sewage.  It was significant enough such that Israel considered adding a vaccination with the live virus after patients received the inactive version.   Also, patients vaccinated with the inactivated virus can still transmit the live virus.  It can go from person-to-person until it finds that un-vaccinated individual.  Any civil disruptions in a country that stop vaccinations can cause it to re-appear.   Only 1 in 200 patients show paralysis, so even among the unvaccinated, it can silently be transmitted.  (In the Ukraine example below, there were likely 100s of other people who also had polio, but didn't show signs).   Hence, I'm much less optimistic than others that Africa will remain free until 2017.

RichStenberg makes a very good case for 80% from a probabilistic standpoint. Darren's point is also valid that weighting too heavily from the get go can have a negative impact on the Brier score. So, I'm splitting the difference between these for now.

This is one of those cases where a single event any time over the next sixteen months causes the answer to be no and this question closes, but to get a yes, the question remains open for the whole time.  This means that there is no value is putting down your true probabilistic assumption (such as RichStenberg's excellent analysis of 80%), as this doesn't optimise the Brier score.  What, you say? Alas, this is so. I've run the numbers for a number of these on past cases and almost came up with an elegant formula, but I tend to get stymied with the very large number of variables. However, based on my experience in instances such as this where the scoring doesn't end for a coon's age (about 480 days if the answer is yes) the penalty from over bidding on the event materialising is low for the first couple of months, where as the reward is higher.  So even though I like the logic around the 80%, I am going to optimise my Brier score with a bid for 60%.  Personally, I don't like that the scoring of these types questions create an incentive not to publicise one's real probabilistic thoughts, but I do like these types of questions.

First impression guess here, 80.  There have been 13 months polio-free, but in one out of the last 14 months (the one longest ago) there was a case of polio.  The time frame is 16 months to go.  100 percent /14 months = 7 percent chance a month (high) down to a zero percent chance (low) if you'd like to believe it's eradicated, no way it could spread from elsewhere, etc.  7 percent a month leaves a 93 percent chance it hasn't happened by next month to the power of 16 months leaves a 29 percent chance of Africa being polio-free after 16 months.  If I split the difference between 29 and 100 percent, since I think a seven percent chance a month is too high, I get 64.5 (remarkably similar to someone else's guess).  If I split the difference between 0 percent and 7 percent, and go with (1.00-.035)^16, that works out to 54.6 percent.  However, what do we know about eradication of other diseases, or any other analagous cases?  If the per-month chance of it coming back is really only 2 percent, then the advance probability of continued eradication by then is "really" closer to 72 percent.  And if you figure a 2 percent chance this month, but only a one percent change 8 months from now, and only a .5 percent chance 8 months after that (probably closer to how a good actuarial model of these events might really look), then the probability of longer-term eradication only goes up from there.  Some research into past cases of disease eradication might clarify what the marginal probability each month really might be, and better frame the overall chances.
